snippet: The Metro reporters of The New York Times outline developments they expect to track in coming months.
abstract: Clyde Haberman introduces predictions from New York Times Metropolitan reporters about the developments they expect to track in New York City in 2012. Drawings (L)1

byline.original: By CLYDE HABERMAN, THOMAS KAPLAN, LIZ ROBBINS, KATE TAYLOR, RAYMOND HERNANDEZ, JOHN ELIGON, MOSI SECRET, BENJAMIN WEISER, CHARLES V. BAGLI, PATRICK McGEEHAN, FERNANDA SANTOS, MIREYA NAVARRO, ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS, KIRK SEMPLE, LISA W. FODERARO, MICHAEL M. GRYNBAUM and AL BAKER

lead_paragraph: THE only safe thing to say about the future is that, borrowing from Mort Sahl, it lies ahead. After that, we are all on our own. The year just past provided ample evidence of the unpredictable nature of that elusive quantity known as news. Who, on Jan. 1, 2011, could have foreseen the Dominique Strauss-Kahn sexual assault case, or Tropical Storm née Hurricane Irene, or the relatively stress-free passage of a same-sex marriage law, or Representative Anthony D. Weiner's political death by tweet, or the rise of the Occupy Wall Street movement, or -- ending the year on a painful note -- the killing of Police Officer Peter J. Figoski?
